p.s: The character Helen, from the novel Gun Love, written by Jennifer Clement, published in 2019, is a very confused and pitiful character because has been through too many foster homes.
Helen is aan eight yearsyear old female foster child.
She doesn't look like eight, she looks about five (l. 2), this is also a reason why she is tinier than Pearl, who is very tiny too.

The information where she was born, or if she got any siblings, is unclear because she lived all her life at a foster home and she thinks that she is from Ethiopia and Finland, she was born in a house, and in a hospital, and she got ten brothers, a twin brother, eleven sisters and two twin sisters (comparatively l. 7-9).
All beside this Helen is loyal and likes cats and forehead kisses (l. 14, l. 19, l. 34-35).
She likes cats that much that she behaves sometimes like a cat, for example she crawls over to Pearl and rubbs her forehead against Pearl's upper arm (l. 41-42).
Maybe she behaves like a cat because many people like cats and she also wants to be liked or accepted.
Everyone treats cats good and she was treated very badly, so she tries to behave like a cat to get treated better.
She often speaks about her in the third pearsonperson what causes a mental illness (l. 17).
She also knows some tricks to get a big effect for nearly no money, like putting clothers with bugs into the microwave to kill the bugs.
This shows the hard things she lived troughthrough and the bad living conditions at the foster homes before.
Helen got a good relationship to Leo, Pearl, Lulu, Gina and Romey, so she isn't compleatelycompletely alone.
These friends give her a sense of life.
Poorly beside these friends she hasn't got any sense of life, like Pearl analyses (l. 23).
To sum it up Helen is a pearsonperson with a good soul living a cracked livelife she doesn't deservesdeserve.
Through this characterisation I can point out Helen's problems now.
At first she is undernourished because she never got something to eat because she was treated so badly and also because of this she drinks not enough (l. 19).
The second, also very big, problem is her mental illness.
